data.text: Cash remains safe to use. People used less cash when the pandemic hit, partly for fear of infection. Our colleagues joined forces with researchers @VirologyBochum and found that the risk of transmission via euro banknotes and coins is very small. Read more https://t.co/DtpXSEQaEt https://t.co/0w2o29zki8

Panetta: The digital euro will complement cash, offering everyone the option to use a universally accepted, risk-free and costless digital means of payments. No one will be left on the sidelines. Read the full interview
EN https://t.co/T3TgKvUMZ9
IT https://t.co/tdAclTZ08b 4/4

Panetta: Our new strategy means that we will respond forcefully to shocks that push inflation below our target. When inflation is picking up, we will be patient and only raise rates when we’re convinced that inflation can be firmly anchored at 2% in the medium term 3/4

Panetta: We have clarified that we want an inflation rate in the medium term of 2%, not below 2%. We have also clarified that 2% is not an ultimate limit - we can temporarily go slightly above to anchor expectations and pursue our target symmetrically 2/4

(THREAD) The risks of an incomplete recovery are still high, while the risks of the economy overheating and high inflation are still contained, Executive Board member Fabio Panetta tells @Corriere. Fiscal policy and monetary policy must continue to support the economy 1/4 https://t.co/QVHVL986di

Panetta: With this paradigm, Europe has moved away from austerity and built on synergies between demand and supply policies. Upgrading EMU governance in this mould will put the recovery and post-crisis economy on a stronger footing. Read the blog post https://t.co/3FRae9DTuw 4/4

Panetta: New European fiscal instruments such as NGEU have set a new paradigm: they ensure faster, broad-based recoveries and make it easier for EU countries to transform their economies, benefitting all through higher productivity growth and positive demand spillovers 3/4

Panetta: With the complete reopening of the economy in sight, we will have to shift from offsetting lost income to adding new income, and from preserving productive capacity to reallocating capital and labour towards sectors with more favourable opportunities 2/4

(THREAD) If we make the recovery fund work and if we embed the lessons from the pandemic in the EMU governance framework, we can emerge from the crisis with a stronger economy and greater social and political cohesion, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta in The ECB Blog 1/4 https://t.co/nZw9Vsjgss

Our persistent support is still needed to bring inflation back to 2% over the medium term.

We decided to keep up the pace of our asset purchases under our pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP) to keep financing conditions favourable.

This helps the current rebound to turn into a lasting recovery and to offset the pandemic’s impact on inflation

Our experimental work has already allowed us to identify possible ways to protect privacy. It has also shown that the energy needs of the infrastructure would be negligible compared with the energy consumption and environmental footprint of crypto-assets, such as bitcoin 2/3

Lagarde: The new strategy gives us the ability to be flexible around the 2%, because 2% is not a ceiling and there will be oscillation. 
We also recognise that all the tools in our toolbox are effective and that we will have to continue using some of them. 
3/3

Lagarde: Now we have a simple, solid and symmetric 2% inflation target:
[1] simple because it removes any ambiguity
[2] solid because it gives us space to manoeuvre our monetary policy
[3] symmetric because we consider deviations up or down as equally undesirable 
2/3

Transcript with Q&A of yesterday’s strategy review press conference https://t.co/0eazidclzp
Watch again: President @Lagarde on the key features of our strategy review https://t.co/uPf5GsPjSm

Communication
Listening events with the public will continue. Press conference statements will be more concise and our monetary policy communication more visual and accessible. We have started with cartoons and texts in plain English on our review https://t.co/luaJTUdnHD 7/7 https://t.co/zORCeLqjtA

Climate change
This is an existential challenge for the world and of strategic importance for our mandate. We will account explicitly for the implications of climate change and the carbon transition in our new strategy. Read our action plan https://t.co/03UAPKCPuS 6/7

Our monetary policy toolkit
We have also carefully reviewed the appropriateness of the instruments in our monetary policy toolkit. The set of ECB policy rates will remain our primary instrument. But the ECB will continue to employ other instruments when the need arises 5/7

A symmetric target
The Governing Council’s commitment to the two per cent target is symmetric. Symmetry means that we consider negative and positive deviations of inflation from the target to be equally undesirable 3/7

A new price stability objective
We have amended our formulation of the price stability objective to a two per cent inflation target over the medium term. This gives more clarity about our objective and helps better anchor inflation expectations 2/7

The recovery may lift the euro area out of the low growth, low inflation environment, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. Monetary policy needs to remain expansionary to set in motion a virtuous circle of rising inflation expectations and wages https://t.co/mffZDNN27j https://t.co/MnH1FKuhg7

Enria: Our supervisory guidance on leveraged lending has not been sufficiently implemented by banks. We plan to deploy the full range of supervisory tools available to us, including minimum capital requirements 3/4

Enria: Excessive risk-taking in markets such as the market for leveraged credit and complex equity derivatives threatens to leave banks overly exposed to sudden adjustments and asset price corrections 2/3

(THREAD) The worst phase of the pandemic is over, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. But we should not lose sight of emerging risks such as increased leverage, complexity and opaqueness in financial markets https://t.co/grqBGxTyXN 1/3 https://t.co/Q4czhzYHDf

Lagarde on structural reforms: at the European level, there must now be a major push to modernise economies. It’s not enough to say “let’s be green, let’s go digital”; we must implement the necessary reforms https://t.co/FpTwhk3lNO 3/3
Lagarde on inflation: base effects, which are related to petrol prices and the rate of VAT in Germany, will not last. We will see a return to lower inflation rates as indicated in our projections 2/3
